MICHEL DEGRAFF: My
name is Michel DeGraff,

and I've been teaching
in linguistics at MIT

And I'm the faculty
instructor for the course

on Creole languages and
Caribbean identities.

So my research is about
trying to understand

And what happens when new
languages are created.

Say, for example, in the
Caribbean in my native Haiti

where Haitian Creole emerged
in the 17th, 18th century.

So we try to understand
that patterns of development

of the languages we
call creole languages.

And in terms of the
structure, but also I

have an applied side
to my work where

I try to understand how
best to use say, Haitian

Creole and other local
languages in education

and how that's crucial
for development
